channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: Senior BNP Paribas Executive to Depart Amid Investigation
item.description: Georges Chodron de Courcel, one of the French bank’s chief operating officers, is retiring after a 42-year career, the bank said in a statement that made no mention of a United States sanctions investigation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Georges Chodron de Courcel, one of BNP Paribas’s three chief operating officers.

item.title: Palestinian Authority Premier Says Unity Government Lacks Power in Gaza
item.description: Rami Hamdallah said that not much had changed since the new government took over and that reconciliation between the West Bank and Gaza Strip would take time.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rami Hamdallah, who has been prime minister for a year, said he was dissatisfied with his new cabinet, which was selected through negotiations between the Fatah-dominated Palestine Liberation Organization and Hamas.

item.title: Bits Blog: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
item.description: The start-up that digitally links passengers and freelance drivers has expanded beyond the United States to cities including London, Paris and Berlin — all of them the sites of Wednesday’s protests.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cabbies in London and other cities demonstrated against the taxi-service app Uber. Page B3.

item.title: Iraq Nears Fracture as Kurd Forces Move Into Oil Town
item.description: The fracturing in Iraq deepened Thursday as Kurdish forces poured into the strategic northern oil city of Kirkuk after government troops fled, while emboldened Sunni militants moved closer to Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SUADAD AL-SALHY and ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 12
item.description: The FIFA World Cup soccer tournament will begin in Brazil on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Harsh Sentence Feared for Detained Rights Lawyer
item.description: The prospect of the imminent release of Pu Zhiqiang, a human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, is growing dim.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pu Zhiqiang speaking to reporters outside Chongqing Higher People's Court in December 2012.

item.title: India Ink: AirAsia India Sets Off on Maiden Flight
item.description: The budget airline AirAsia India has taken off on its maiden flight, the first airline with foreign investment to do so in India.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: An Air Asia India aircraft preparing to embark for its inaugural flight to Goa from the Kempe Gowda International Airport in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Sees American ‘Adventurism’ in Iraq Behind Current Conflict
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, said the United States’ withdrawal of forces from Iraq was premature and contributed to the recent terrorism there.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: P.L.A. in Lights
item.description: The Hong Kong light and laser show this week appeared to include gigantic Chinese characters that read “People’s Liberation Army” on the side of the garrison’s waterfront headquarters, alarming many locals.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Campaign to Crack Down on Fringe Sects in China Worries Mainstream Churches
item.description: The campaign was prompted by the murder of a woman at a McDonald’s that horrified the nation and was attributed to adherents of a religious group.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: China Central Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Zhang Lidong is described as the ringleader of a deadly attack.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Scottish Independence Vote Cuts England, Wales and Northern Ireland Out of the Equation
item.description: The decision on whether Scotland breaks away will be made by a small fraction of the people who stand to see their notions of national identity upended.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: China Accuses Japan of Aggressive Airborne Acts
item.description: China contradicted Japan’s account of the latest close encounters between military aircraft, further escalating tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Second Drone Strike in Pakistan Suggests Freer Hand for U.S.
item.description: The strikes were apparently aimed at the Haqqani network, a Taliban-allied faction that until last month held the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl hostage.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Beijing’s Pressure Tactics in Hong Kong
item.description: A former Hong Kong leader says the city needs to be tougher in dealing with Beijing, or else face the consequences sooner rather than later.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Anson Chan, former chief secretary of Hong Kong.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Abe and the Fourth Estate
item.description: Many of Japan’s journalists naturally drift closer to authority over time.
item.dc:creator: By NORIHIRO KATO

item.title: European Court Upholds $1.44 Billion Fine Against Intel
item.description: The American technology giant had been appealing a decision where it was found to have abused its dominant position in computer chips.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Intel still can appeal the case to Europe’s highest court, the European Court of Justice.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: An Interview With Xi, Long Before He Was China’s Leader
item.description: In a 2004 interview, Xi Jinping talks about his hard years on a farm when his family was out of political favor.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: Greenpeace and Other Advocates Fear Clampdown After Leaked Report
item.description: An intelligence report leaked to the local media charged foreign-funded nongovernmental organizations with stalling economic progress.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: All Justice Is Local
item.description: Small communities in Rwanda and Uganda are revolutionizing postconflict justice.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By PHIL CLARK

item.title: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Strip Kills Palestinian
item.description: The airstrike that killed a Palestinian, who was believed to be a militant, and injured two others came hours after a rocket fired from Gaza hit southern Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi of Two Minds: Be a Good Neighbor, or Assert China’s Power?
item.description: A new report says that President Xi Jinping is torn between ambitions to have China exert power over Asia and a desire for peace in the region so he can focus on domestic priorities.
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, left, with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a regional summit meeting in Shanghai last month. A report says Mr. Xi has pursued a complicated, if not contradictory, course of assertiveness and conciliation.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: With World Cup Near, Airport Staff Plans Strike
item.description: The workers at Rio de Janeiro’s airports said they would go on a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the opening day of the World Cup soccer tournament.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Brothers Sentenced Again for Cannibalism
item.description: An antiterrorism court in Punjab Province on Wednesday sentenced two brothers accused of cannibalism each to 11 years and four months in prison.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: World Briefing: Ugandan Official to Be Next General Assembly Chief
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly chose Sam Kutesa, Uganda’s foreign minister, as its next president, bypassing concerns of rights advocates and Western officials over Uganda’s law criminalizing homosexuality.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: White House Outlines Steps to Protect Covert Identities
item.description: The moves are in reaction to the accidental revelation last month of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top spy in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
